awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Enabling Student Project Collaboration with Artificial Intelligence Augmented Mentorship
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project is in improving both student learning and workforce readiness through interdependent learning experiences. The project will create project-based environments that promote skills such as communication, critical thinking, problem solving, time management, creativity, and teamwork – all mirroring professional work environments. The technology will also promote development of skills such as project management, writing, business and data analysis, design, and presentation. Project collaboration requires that students interact frequently throughout the project completion process, including frequent mentor or teacher interactions. Such an interdependent environment creates a real-world dynamic that better prepares students to enter the workforce. The platform developed by this project is likely to create significant societal impact while participating in the fastest growing e-learning sector.

The proposal seeks to develop a collaborative community platform using proprietary project collaboration models integrated with Artificial Intelligence (AI) augmented mentorship to enhance student workforce readiness. The technology will be designed to provide the right piece of information to the students and mentors at the right time. By analyzing and unifying all the content under a domain-specific semantic representation, the system will be able to aggregate and organize all the content and identify the piece for intervention that is contextually most useful.  To make project collaboration and mentorship easier between students and mentors in a trustworthy manner, modeling will be done utilizing minimal supervision. This modelling will include combining contextual embeddings from language models with graph-based neural networks to capture interactions across multiple facets.  The technology will build upon explainability of deep neural networks to provide an appropriate level of transparency into the decision making, both for the users to learn to trust the platform, as well as for the platform developers to build systems that aid in reliable, trustworthy, and fair mentoring.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The widening divide between educators and employers creates a critical skills gap hindering U.S. economic competitiveness. Employers struggle to find qualified talent with the right mix of technical hard skills and soft skills. Graduates, on the other hand, often lack the specific skills needed for today's technology-driven jobs. Traditional educational approaches with outdated curricula and limited industry relevance fail to prepare students for the realities of the workforce. Bridging this divide requires students to gain relevant professional experiences that cultivate in-demand 21st century skills.  LC tackles this challenge by merging Collaborative Project-Based Learning (CPBL) with advanced AI/ML technologies. This scalable platform aims to boost student skill development and workforce readiness. 

Our project focuses on two core objectives:

  1. Design, develop and validate a CPBL technology that empowers students and instructors to create projects, build teams, manage workflows with industry mentors, track skill development and build a portfolio of work.

  2. Build and validate standalone AI/ML models and Large Language Models (LLMs) to enhance user experience, support personalized instruction, and deliver data-driven insights.  

Understanding user needs was central to our work. We conducted in-depth interviews with over 200 educators, administrators, industry professionals, companies, and workforce experts. Key findings included a strong emphasis on student mentorship (95%), collaborative project-based learning (66%), and skills development (86%). 

Our research revealed significant student pain points:

  • A staggering 68% of students lack the skills and experience employers seek, hindering their ability to secure their desired careers.

  • 71% of students struggle to secure the necessary opportunities to develop their workforce skills, leaving them unprepared for the demands of the modern workplace.

  • A concerning 82% of students lack access to career counseling, hindering their ability to make informed decisions about their future and choose appropriate academic paths.

  • 43% of students identified the need to build a work portfolio to showcase their skills and experience to potential employers, but lack guidance and opportunity.

  • Disappointingly, 37% of students felt their degrees did not directly translate to jobs in their chosen field.

Instructors also face challenges in preparing students for the workforce:

  • Striking a balance between fulfilling teaching requirements, managing group projects, and ensuring individual student needs are met proved difficult for 89% of instructors.

  • Limited access to training resources hinders 78% of instructors from effectively preparing students for the evolving workplace and teaching the latest in-demand skills.

  • 66% of instructors highlighted the need for strategies to effectively engage students from diverse backgrounds and learning styles, ensuring an inclusive learning environment benefiting all students.

  • Measuring the effectiveness of curriculum in terms of job placement success remains a challenge for 73% of instructors, making it difficult to adapt and improve their teaching methods.

Companies expressed concerns about the preparedness of graduates entering the workforce:

  • 61% of companies believe college students are unprepared for the demands of the modern workplace, lacking practical skills and real-world experience.

  • 57% of companies reported a lack of effective communication with academic institutions, hindering collaboration and alignment with industry needs, making it difficult to bridge the skills gap.

  • Budget constraints limit the ability of 42% of companies to provide the necessary training for students to bridge the skills gap, placing the burden on students themselves.

We built an MVP prioritizing hard and soft skills development and aiding instructors in creating and managing project-based assignments. The platform fosters collaboration between students and instructors, working alongside industry mentors. Users can join projects, set role-based goals, track progress, and build a skill portfolio. The mentorship component enhances professional networking, giving students a competitive edge in the job market. This holistic approach prepares students academically, socially, and professionally. The testing of core functionalities yielded positive results, suggesting promise for future classroom implementation and enhanced skills development.  We conducted a series of usability tests with over 60 college learners and instructors to ensure the platform meets user needs and expectations. Their feedback refined the technology to address pain points identified in the user research phase.

We explored AI/ML integration within the CPBL environment, building and testing stand-alone models to identify beneficial uses and outcomes. This research informed the development of personalized learning paths, intelligent support systems that provide targeted feedback and guidance, and data-driven feedback mechanisms. AI refines student concerns into clear queries for mentors and consolidates progress updates, while assisting instructors with designing and organizing group projects as well as creating cohesive teams. Our AI models achieved an 89.3% success rate in generating milestones, goals, tasks, student-mentor questions, and instructor assignment ideas across various subjects. This initial success validates the potential of AI/ML for personalized learning paths and intelligent instructional systems.

Our next research phase involves classroom piloting, product refinement, advanced features, and AI/ML integration. LC has the potential to revolutionize education by equipping students with the skills and experiences needed for the modern workforce, thereby fostering a more competitive and innovative U.S. economy.


Last Modified: 07/03/2024
Modified by: Tracie D Ponder

por.por_txt_cntn:
The widening divide between educators and employers creates a critical skills gap hindering U.S. economic competitiveness. Employers struggle to find qualified talent with the right mix of technical hard skills and soft skills. Graduates, on the other hand, often lack the specific skills needed for today's technology-driven jobs. Traditional educational approaches with outdated curricula and limited industry relevance fail to prepare students for the realities of the workforce. Bridging this divide requires students to gain relevant professional experiences that cultivate in-demand 21st century skills. LC tackles this challenge by merging Collaborative Project-Based Learning (CPBL) with advanced AI/ML technologies. This scalable platform aims to boost student skill development and workforce readiness.


Our project focuses on two core objectives:




Design, develop and validate a CPBL technology that empowers students and instructors to create projects, build teams, manage workflows with industry mentors, track skill development and build a portfolio of work.




Build and validate standalone AI/ML models and Large Language Models (LLMs) to enhance user experience, support personalized instruction, and deliver data-driven insights.




Understanding user needs was central to our work. We conducted in-depth interviews with over 200 educators, administrators, industry professionals, companies, and workforce experts. Key findings included a strong emphasis on student mentorship (95%), collaborative project-based learning (66%), and skills development (86%).


Our research revealed significant student pain points:




A staggering 68% of students lack the skills and experience employers seek, hindering their ability to secure their desired careers.




71% of students struggle to secure the necessary opportunities to develop their workforce skills, leaving them unprepared for the demands of the modern workplace.




A concerning 82% of students lack access to career counseling, hindering their ability to make informed decisions about their future and choose appropriate academic paths.




43% of students identified the need to build a work portfolio to showcase their skills and experience to potential employers, but lack guidance and opportunity.




Disappointingly, 37% of students felt their degrees did not directly translate to jobs in their chosen field.




Instructors also face challenges in preparing students for the workforce:




Striking a balance between fulfilling teaching requirements, managing group projects, and ensuring individual student needs are met proved difficult for 89% of instructors.




Limited access to training resources hinders 78% of instructors from effectively preparing students for the evolving workplace and teaching the latest in-demand skills.




66% of instructors highlighted the need for strategies to effectively engage students from diverse backgrounds and learning styles, ensuring an inclusive learning environment benefiting all students.




Measuring the effectiveness of curriculum in terms of job placement success remains a challenge for 73% of instructors, making it difficult to adapt and improve their teaching methods.




Companies expressed concerns about the preparedness of graduates entering the workforce:




61% of companies believe college students are unprepared for the demands of the modern workplace, lacking practical skills and real-world experience.

Budget constraints limit the ability of 42% of companies to provide the necessary training for students to bridge the skills gap, placing the burden on students themselves.

The platform fosters collaboration between students and instructors, working alongside industry mentors. Users can join projects, set role-based goals, track progress, and build a skill portfolio. The mentorship component enhances professional networking, giving students a competitive edge in the job market. This holistic approach prepares students academically, socially, and professionally. Their feedback refined the technology to address pain points identified in the user research phase.
